{{EngvarB|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Conor Coady | image = Conor Coady.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Coady training for [[England national under-19 football team|England U19s]] during the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]] | fullname = Conor David Coady<ref>{{Cite news|title=Premier League Clubs submit Squad Lists |url=http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/Premier-League-Squad-Lists-January-2014.pdf |publisher=Premier League |format=PDF |page=19 |date=4 February 2014 |accessdate=11 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140316063138/http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/Premier-League-Squad-Lists-January-2014.pdf |archivedate=16 March 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1993|2|25|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Haydock]], England | height = {{height|ft=6|in=1}} | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | currentclub = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | clubnumber = 16 | youthyears1 = 2005–2013 |youthclubs1 = [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy|Liverpool]] | years1 = 2012–2014 |clubs1 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] |caps1 = 1 |goals1 = 0<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years2 = 2013–2014 |clubs2 = → [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] (loan) |caps2 = 39 |goals2 = 5<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years3 = 2014–2015 |clubs3 = [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] |caps3 = 45 |goals3 = 3<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years4 = 2015– |clubs4 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |caps4 = 148 |goals4 = 1<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | nationalyears1 = 2009 |nationalteam1=[[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] |nationalcaps1 = 4 |nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2009–2010|nationalteam2=[[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] |nationalcaps2 = 17 |nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2010–2011|nationalteam3=[[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] |nationalcaps3 = 2 |nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2011 |nationalteam4=[[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] |nationalcaps4 = 12 |nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2013 |nationalteam5=[[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] |nationalcaps5 = 4 |nationalgoals5 = 1 | club-update = 00:07, 12 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Conor David Coady''' (born 25 February 1993) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].
Coady came through the academy system at his local side [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and made two appearances for the senior side before spending a season on loan at [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] and then moving to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on a permanent transfer in 2014. He has also represented England at youth level, being named in the team of the tournament as England won the [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]] and captaining the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20]] team at the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2013 under-20 World Cup]].
==Club career== ===Liverpool=== Born in [[Liverpool]], Coady grew up supporting [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref name="liverpool supporter">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/sheff-utd/sheffield-united-conor-would-be-keen-on-lane-option-1-6591466|title=Conor would be keen on Lane option|publisher=The Sheffield Star|date=2 May 2014|accessdate=2 May 2014}}</ref> He is a product of the [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy|Liverpool Youth Academy]] after joining the club in 2005. During the [[2010–11 Liverpool F.C. season|2010–11 season]], Coady was on the fringes of the first team, making the subs bench twice but failed to make a first team appearance.<ref>{{cite web|last=Whyatt|first=Chris|title=Sparta Prague 0 – 0 Liverpool|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/9399199.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 March 2013|date=17 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dawkes|first=Phil|title=Liverpool 9 – 1 Birmingham|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9463392.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 March 2013|date=23 April 2011}}</ref> Coady played every [[Barclays Premier Reserve League|Reserve League]] and [[NextGen Series]] match during the [[2011–12 Liverpool F.C. season|2011–12 season]], scoring five goals. Despite being named in the senior squad list and being called up to the senior squad occasionally from 2009, he did not make his senior début until 8 November 2012 in a [[UEFA Europa League]] group stage match against [[Anzhi Makhachkala]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20164149|title=Anzhi Makhachkala 1–0 Liverpool|date=8 November 2012|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> After [[Andre Wisdom]]'s promotion as a full-time senior squad member, Conor Coady was installed as full-time captain of the Under-21 squad and on 12 May 2013 he made his Premier League début in a 3–1 win at [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Seven starlets who stepped up in 2012–13|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/seven-starlets-who-stepped-up-in-2012-13|publisher=Liverpool FC|accessdate=23 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402152829/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/seven-starlets-who-stepped-up-in-2012-13|archive-date=2 April 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Coady agreed a six-month loan deal with [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on 22 July 2013,<ref name="blades loan">{{cite web|url=http://www.sufc.co.uk/news/article/20130722-coady-in-on-loan-936404.aspx|title=Coady in on loan|publisher=Sheffield United F.C.|date=22 July 2013|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> later stating that he had turned down the chance to go on Liverpool's pre-season tour of Australia and the Far East in order to join up with his new club.<ref name="Rodgers influence">{{cite news|title=Coady reveals Rodgers influence|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11683/8836859/coady-reveals-rodgers-infleunce|accessdate=23 July 2013|publisher=Sky Sports News|date=23 July 2013}}</ref> Coady made his debut for the Blades in the opening fixture of the following season, coming on as a second-half substitute in a 2–1 home victory over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]],<ref name="blades debut">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/aug/02/sheffield-united-notts-county-report|title=Sheffield United's David Weir off to winning start against Notts County|work=The Guardian|date=2 August 2013|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref> and made his first start for the club in the following game, a [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] first round defeat to [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23499353|title=Sheffield United 1–2 Burton|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 August 2013|accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref>
Coady scored his first senior goal in a 1–1 draw at [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on 30 November 2013.<ref name="blades goal">{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/288435/report|title=Cox snatches point for Orient|publisher=Sky Sports|date=30 November 2013|accessdate=2 December 2013}}</ref> Having been in and out of the side during the first half of the season, Coady began to cement a regular first-team place over the Christmas period, prompting United to extend his loan spell during the January transfer window,<ref name="blades loan extension">{{cite news|title=Liverpool youngster Conor Coady extends loan spell with Sheffield United|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/liverpool-youngster-conor-coady-extends-3001910|accessdate=10 January 2014|work=Daily Mirror|date=8 January 2014}}</ref> and once more in February to extend his stay until the end of the season.<ref name="coady end season">{{cite news|title=Liverpool midfielder extends Sheffield United loan deal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26338499|accessdate=25 February 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 February 2014}}</ref> Coady played regularly for the Blades for the remainder of the season and returned to [[Anfield]] having played 50 games and scored six goals.<ref name="1314apps">{{Soccerbase season|58424|2013|name=Conor Coady|accessdate=11 May 2014}}</ref>
===Huddersfield Town=== On 6 August 2014, Coady signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on a three-year deal for a fee, believed to be around £500,000.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Conor Coady Joins Huddersfield Town |url=http://www.htafc.com/news/article/first-team-news-conor-coady-1809298.aspx |publisher=Huddersfield Town F.C |date=6 August 2014 |accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref> He made his début as a substitute in the 4–0 defeat by [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] on 9 August.<ref name="stats"/> On 1 October, he scored his first goal for the club against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] where Town won 3–1 at [[Molineux Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Huddersfield Town earned a surprise win away at Wolves to stop the hosts going top of the Championship.|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29338891|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> He again found the net, this time in a 2–2 draw against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rotherham United 2 Huddersfield Town 2|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/30543342|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref>
===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== [[File:Coady Ralls.jpg|thumbnail|Coady (left) defending against [[Joe Ralls]].]]
On 3 July 2015, Coady signed for Championship club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on a three-year deal for an undisclosed fee, believed to be around £2 million.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Conor Coady: Wolves sign Huddersfield Town midfielder|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33380799|publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 July 2015}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Wolves in a 2–1 [[EFL Cup]] win against [[Crawley Town]] on 9 August 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36949401|title=Wolves 2–1 Crawley|publisher=BBC Sport|date=9 August 2016|accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref>
As of the start of the 2017–18 season, Coady has, at the behest of Wolves' manager [[Nuno Espírito Santo]], played at centre-half in a three-man defence for Wolves.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2017/09/22/delighted-conor-coady-signs-four-year-wolves-contract/|title=Delighted Conor Coady signs four-year Wolves contract|work=[[Express & Star]]|date=22 September 2017|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
It was announced in September 2017 that Coady had signed a new four-year contract with Wolves, running until summer 2021.<ref>{{cite news|title=Four more years!|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20170922-four-more-years/|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C|date=22 September 2017}}</ref>
On 21 April 2018, during his 120th league appearance for Wolves, Coady scored a 66th minute penalty in a 4–0 win against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] to get his first league goal for the club, as Wolves sealed the [[EFL Championship]] title.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bolton Wanderers 0-4 Wolves|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43762334|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=21 April 2018}}</ref>
It was announced on 15 February 2019 that Coady had put pen to paper on a new contract that would keep him at Wolverhampton Wanderers until the summer of 2023.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wolves: Conor Coady and Matt Doherty sign new deals until 2023|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47260570|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=15 February 2019|accessdate=16 February 2019}}</ref>
==International career== Coady has represented England at Under-16 right through to Under-20 level.<ref name="FA">{{cite web|title=The FA profile|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players/C/Conor-Coady|publisher=The FA|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> He has been capped 17 times for the [[England national under-17 football team]].<ref name="FA"/> He played and captained<ref>{{cite web|title=England U-17s beat Spain to win European Championship|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/8713980.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> the England team at the [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]] in Liechtenstein where he and his England colleagues won the tournament, and became the first England team to win an international tournament in 17 years.<ref name="win">{{cite web|last=Rice|first=Jimmy|title=Wisdom scores in historic triumph|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/wisdom-scores-in-historic-triumph|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|accessdate=9 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402152924/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/wisdom-scores-in-historic-triumph|archive-date=2 April 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He was then part of the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]] in Estonia<ref>{{cite web|last=Rice|first=Jimmy|title=LFC duo named in U19s Euro squad|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/lfc-duo-named-in-u19s-euro-squad|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|accessdate=9 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904141407/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/lfc-duo-named-in-u19s-euro-squad|archivedate=4 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> in which England got as far as the semi-finals where they were knocked out by [[Greece national under-19 football team|Greece]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Hunter|first=Steve|title=Final joy for Suso as England lose|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/final-joy-for-suso-as-england-lose|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|accessdate=9 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026185722/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/final-joy-for-suso-as-england-lose|archive-date=26 October 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He was named captain of the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20 team]] by manager [[Peter Taylor (footballer born 1953)|Peter Taylor]] for the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/conor-coady-to-captain-young-lions-fifa-world-cup|title=Captain Coady|publisher=The Football Association|date=11 June 2013|accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref> He made his debut for the side on 16 June, in a 3–0 win in a warm-up game against [[Uruguay national under-20 football team|Uruguay]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/uruguay-report-160613 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130624222816/http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/uruguay-report-160613 |dead-url=yes |archivedate=24 June 2013 |title=England U20s continue World Cup preparations with a 3–0 win over Uruguay |publisher=The Football Association |date=16 June 2013 |accessdate=17 June 2013 }}</ref> On 23 June, he scored in the opening group-stage game against [[Iraq national under-20 football team|Iraq]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/iraq-updates-230613|title=England v Iraq|publisher=The Football Association|date=23 June 2013|accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref>
==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|2 March 2019}}<ref name="stats">{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=58424|title=Conor Coady|publisher=Soccerbase|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !rowspan="2" |Club !rowspan="2" |Season !colspan="3" |League !colspan="2" |FA Cup !colspan="2" |League Cup !colspan="2" |Other !colspan="2" |Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] |[[2012–13 Liverpool F.C. season|2012–13]] |[[Premier League]] |1||0||0||0||0||0||1||0||2||0 |- |[[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] (loan) |[[2013–14 Sheffield United F.C. season|2013–14]] |[[EFL League One|League One]] |39||5||8||1||1||0||2||0||50||6 |- |[[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] |[[2014–15 Huddersfield Town A.F.C. season|2014–15]] |[[EFL Championship|Championship]] |45||3||1||0||2||0||0||0||48||3 |- !colspan="3"|Total !85!!8!!9!!1!!3!!0!!3!!0!!100!!9 |- |rowspan="5"|[[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |[[2015–16 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2015–16]] |Championship |37||0||1||0||1||0||0||0||39||0 |- |[[2016–17 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2016–17]] |Championship |40||0||2||0||3||1||0||0||45||1 |- |[[2017–18 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2017–18]] |Championship |45||1||1||0||2||0||0||0||48||1 |- |[[2018–19 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2018–19]] |Premier League |29||0||4||0||2||0||0||0||35||0 |- !colspan="2"|Wolves total !151!!1!!8!!0!!8!!1!!0!!0!!167!!2 |- ! colspan="3" |Career total !236!!9!!17!!1!!11!!1!!3!!0!!267!!11 |}
==Honours== '''Wolverhampton Wanderers''' *[[EFL Championship]]: [[2017–18 EFL Championship|2017–18]]<ref>{{cite book |editor-first=John |editor-last=Anderson |title=Football Yearbook 2018–2019 |year=2018 |publisher=Headline Publishing Group |location=London |isbn=978-1-4722-6106-9 |pages=386–387}}</ref>
'''England U17''' *[[UEFA European Under-17 Championship]]: [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Championship|2010]]<ref name="win"/>
'''Individual''' *UEFA European Under-17 Championship Team of the Tournament: [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Championship#Technical team selection|2010]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.uefa.com/MultimediaFiles/Download/TechnicalReport/competitions/Under19/01/65/10/43/1651043_DOWNLOAD.pdf |title=Technical Report |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> *EFL Championship Team of the Season: [[2017–18 EFL Championship|2017–18]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/news/2018/april/efl-awards-2018-shortlists-revealed |title=EFL Awards 2018: Shortlists Revealed |publisher=English Football League |date=3 April 2018}}</ref>
